Reviews.Title: The perfect solution for commuter students.
Reviews.Author: Tony Abella "Tony"
Reviews.Content: I commute to university on public transit and I used to take my heavy laptop to school every day because I thought it was the best method for typing notes and accessing eTextbooks. I started looking at tablets because I was tired of lugging around that heavy computer all the time. I was looking in the 7 inch range for one-handed use but I decided that there was no way an on screen keyboard could keep up with taking lecture notes.Someone on reddit's Android subreddit introduced me to the Note 8 and I was immediately hooked on the idea of handwritten notes on a tablet. After trying it out in a local electronics store (where they were asking $399) I knew that this was the tablet to replace my laptop. The S-Pen doesn't track instantaneously, but it's fast enough to feel natural when writing and drawing. My only gripe with S-Pen is that the button on the stylus is a bit hard to press, but that's the nitpickiest nitpick there is.I'm not totally in love with TouchWiz, Samsung's "skin" that they place over Android to include their own looks and features. My phone runs mostly stock Android and has done so for years so I suppose it's merely a matter of preference so I don't dock it any points. It's not bad, just not the flavor of Android I like best. Fortunately the S-Pen works fine with third party ROMs.The screen is sharp despite the relatively low ppi (pixels per inch, 189ppi) and is great for reading. The colors are too brightly contrasted or harsh and the tablet has a massive brightness range from very bright to VERY dim--perfect for when the professor turns off the lights and turns on the projector.The hardware specs are great and it runs any game with ease. I've considered getting a sacrificial TPU case and a Gameklip for big screen mobile gaming with a controller. 1080p movies and videos playback fine though I wouldn't keep 1080p content on the device, total storage hog, plus the tablet is only 720p despite being able to output 1080p to a TV.I purchased an STM folio case to go along with it, something WITHOUT MAGNETS. I've heard the complaints about magnets damaging the S-Pen functionality and while I don't know if they're definitive, I certainly wouldn't like to find out on my tablet.Overall this is one of the best products I've ever dropped $340 on. Makes you wonder why a smartphone with less capabilities (except the ability to make phone calls, which incidentally the international Note 8 allows it too) can cost up to twice as much with half the useability. This tablet is someone finally figuring out a mobile device for content creation, not just content consumption.

Reviews.Title: Exceptional Device
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Let me say right off the bat that this is indeed a FIVE STAR rated device. No stutter, no lag, runs smooth as silk, PERIOD. This display is bright, the colors are accurate, and operation of various functions are lightning fast. I sold my iPad Mini after purchasing this device. When the Nexus 10 is updated, and a MicroSD slot is added, I will also sell my iPad 3. iPads are also great devices, but they do not offer any user customization at all, nor do they offer MicroSD functionality. Besides, I AM SICK OF APPLE products. Google has hit a home run with the Jellybean operating system. Apple finally has REAL competition in both the phone and tablet space. Great job Google. So long Apple.

Reviews.Title: Good but not great
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Pros:1. I don't have any complaints about build quality. Even though it is plastic, it feels sturdy.2. It weighs the same amount as my Nexus 7 (1st edition) by feel and according to my digital food scale. It is thinner than Nexus 7.3. I do like the 1 inch bigger screen, it is nicer to read on.4. I like the Memory expansion capability for micro-SD. However, App2SD programs can't move my programs to my memory card. I don't want to root it.5. It has better speed than my Nexus 7.6. I like having more memory and storage so that I don't have to watch my consumption much.7. I like the multi-window feature to look at 2 apps at once.Cons:1. If not using a case, I like the grip feel on the back of the Nexus7. The Note 8.0 is smooth and slick.2. I would like this better if the bezels were thinner, The bezels are about .5 inches length sides, and about .75 on the width sides.3. It goes through battery quicker than Nexus 7. It isn't horrible though. It would be nice to only turn on extra CPU cores when you really need them.4. I miss Android 4.3 like on my Samsung S4. Samsung should send out an update to bring us up from 4.1.2.5. It could use a smaller price point.Other thoughts:1. The screen is the same resolution that the Nexus 7 has, so no big change.2. I'm not sure about the pen, it works, but unless you are already a note taker, or doodler, I'm not sure it provides me any useful feature.3. I'm not sure the differences between Note 8.0 and Galaxy Tab 3 8" is worth the extra $80. (i'll update as I discover more things)4. Adobe is lame for not supporting Flash on these anymore, but you can still install if you search for Archived Flash Player or visit [...] There are still so many apps out there that support Flash and I haven't seen anything quite take its place yet.If Google still had their 8 or 9 inch tablet that also had micro sd for storage, I would probably lean towards Google.I guess the biggest things to decide on are:What size of a screen do you need?What screen resolution do you want?How much storage do you need?How much RAM do you need?Do you need quad-core or will dual-core suffice?Do you need the S Pen feature?Update 9-14-2013:Battery, While yes it drains faster than the Nexus 7, it is not bad. After optimizing my battery with Battery HD and then 100% charge, it reads:Music Playback  Internet Browsing8h 20m  WiFi: 12h 30mVideo Playback  Talk Tim (VOIP)16h 40m  WiFi: 10h 0 minSo far after having this device for 9 days, I have found good use for it. Here Are some of my favorites:1. Remote Control (like any software you have to find the one that works for you. The Peel Smart Remote that comes with it does not meet my needs, but it controlled my TV, Blu-ray, and Receiver.2. E-mail. My several personal emails, my work email, and my university email, which is the new Office 365 account.3. Church. I can load all my scriptures, hymns and other studying materials.4. Financial. Mint.com to see where my money is going and how much is spent on fast food.5. Inventory. Movies, Posessions, what is needed at the grocery store, etc. (Even with a barcode scanner!)6. Books and magazines including all my geeks stuff that I am interested in.7. Movies and TV shows.8. Communications like facebook and Skype9. Doodling10. Calculators. standard, scientific, graphing, and handyman that understands fractions that a tape measure uses.11. Games. All sorts. For me, for my kids, it seems to be great for this.12. Flashlight for looking for items you lost in the movie theatre after the movie is over or sneaking into your bedroom while your wife is sleeping and trying not to wake her up because you spent all night trying to figure out new and wonderful things to do with your tablet.

Reviews.Title: What I've been waiting for!
Reviews.Author: Rex Elliott
Reviews.Content: I had been holding off buying, flip / flopping back and forth between a Kindle Fire HD and a bigger Galaxy tablet.  I really prefer the size of the 8 inch screen to the bigger tablet.  For me it is not for work, and the smaller screen is just more convenient.  I was leaning toward the Fire HD when Samsung announced that Note 8 was available.  I immediately did a side by side comparison of the features.  The Kindle screen is just a tad larger, but the Note's thickness  and weight is about half that of the Kindle HD.  Also the notes add on memory was a deal clincher.  I've had this table since it became available and wouldn't think of switching.

Reviews.Title: So far the best I tried
Reviews.Author: Osakapi
Reviews.Content: Expensive? Yes, but comparing with the competition and similar size, quality, memory and screen, it is in line or above.Reviews suggested insufficient battery life - I disagree, this runs a day in heavy use, after that you need to charge any device. Could be better? Yes, but do you need it?Standard micro-USB for charging, computer connection = GRRREAT finally.Very fast, very sensitive and super screen, stylus is a charm to use.8 Inch size, format of screen seems to fit the sweet spot: light, sufficient size and easy to store or carry (like a standard book size, not a binder).With the right (off line) GPS it navigates smooth and fast.Streaming is spotless, movies on Netflix come very high quality. It plays just about any format video or sound file.Music streaming high quality and with no interruptions.Music playback quality is good (not a Cowon, but not bad for a Samsung).Waiting for Android update, I wish unit came with a newer version or updated by now.However Samsung version of simplified Android screens and added functions is good, easier to use while offering all I need.I was hesitant at first, reading a lot of negative reviews. But so far I love it as a home or travel companion.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic tablet for productivity!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I LOVE this tablet!  I did a lot of research before purchasing, read just about every review I could find and I don't have the least bit of regret in the choice that I made.  I bought this to replace an iPad 32GB 1st generation that was starting to behave erratically now that the Apple updates were no longer updating its older software.  My old iPad had been a gift from my husband and had sufficed me well enough over the years but the fact that Apple had essentially phased it out of their updates was frustrating and I wanted something with an expandable memory that wasn't going to cost me an arm and a leg.My biggest hesitation was over whether to purchase the 8.0 or the newer 10.1 2014 edition.  I'm used to the larger size but the sizable price difference between the 8.0 and the 10.1 really made me question whether I had to have the larger screen.  In the end I decided that I could adapt to the smaller screen and it really hasn't been a problem at all.  I've had my Note for less than a week and I'm already completely comfortable with its size.This thing really blows my old iPad out of the water.  I can't speak to how it compares to the newer ones but there's NO comparison to my old one.  My old iPad was essentially an entertainment device, I could use it to watch movies, read books & surf the web, but it was never a very useful productivity tool.  The S Pen is fantastic, although it did feel a little odd at first simply because I wasn't used to using one.  The handwriting-to-text function is really cool and is remarkably effective at translating your writing.  I've had to correct it on a few things but that's really only been when I've allowed my handwriting to deteriorate into total scribble and I don't have particularly neat handwriting to begin with so I didn't have high hopes for this function but it has impressed me quite a bit.I work remotely so I also wanted to make sure that I could use this as a tool for work.  I'm able to log into Citrix Gateway and access my remote desktop exactly as I do on my computer in my home office. This has been incredibly handy already in the last few days as I've had a terrible cold and spent several days working from my couch.  The S Pen is perfect for this as it's like having a tiny portable mouse for your tablet.  Anyone who's ever connected to a remote desktop on a tablet or phone can attest to the fact that it's REALLY hard to navigate effectively if you're using your finger because everything on the screen is so tiny.  I spent two hours yesterday evening working on updating data in an Excel spreadsheet with over 700 rows in it and didn't run into anything that I can do on my computer that I wasn't able to do from my Note.After registering my Note I received an email confirming my registration but never received an email with the advertised Samsung Perks.  I contacted Samsung Customer Support via Facebook and they gave me an email address to contact and told me what information to include.  I sent an email last night and this morning already had a response with the missing information for how to access the Perks so A+ for Samsung's Customer Service as well.  I really couldn't be more satisfied with this tablet!

Reviews.Title: Excellent choice for school and work, a true pleasure to use
Reviews.Author: C. Hann "sparrownotasail"
Reviews.Content: Bought this as a companion to my graduate school studies. Amazing tool for any student, I have been waiting years for truly functional tablet + handwriting technology for years and it is finally here. Could not recommend more. Blazing fast, beautiful screen, good construction, excellent included software, good battery, 4.2.2 update does present some minor problems but fixes are available online (multi window function only). Overall the update was good, though. So happy with my purchase. The extra money you pay for having the S pen technology should not be considered a negative because this kind of technology is unique amongst tablets...if you are considering a tablet for school, I would look no further. Size is perfect and functionality blows any S-pen free tablet right out of the water.

Reviews.Title: I use it everyday
Reviews.Author: brian reviews1
Reviews.Content: I bought the note 8 and 2 weeks later my laptop died. I use it to check email, facebook, surf the net, play games, enter grades for my classes (I'm a teacher). I take it to meetings and love being able to write with the pen just like on paper. I have it make my hand written notes into typed notes. It is amazing on how well it recognizes your handwritting. It will also take dictation notes, but I don't use that as ofen because other people are aound, but it is nice to dictate to it when no one is around. I bought an Anker bloothtooth keyboaard to use when I am at home, and typed my review with it.The size is great, my wife has an iPad, I have an iPhone,  so this is my first android device. I definitly like it better than ios, you have for freedom to do what you want with the tablet. Swype is another nice feature that you can use with the on screen keyboard.I would highly recommenc.

Reviews.Title: Hard to knock it - expensive, but somehow still worth it
Reviews.Author: Zachary S. Stover
Reviews.Content: I purchased one of the brown/black tablets shortly after the release of the new Nexus 7 after looking for a tablet that would be useful for taking notes during meetings at work as well as providing me with a fun, functional tablet.Operating system:The stock operating system of the Note 8.0 is android, and while it is very snappy, it is slightly behind compared to the new Nexus 7 which came with 4.3. The Note 8.0 has some trick functionality built into the Samsung Touchwiz interface, where it automatically loads a list of S-note templates when the s pen is removed from its silo housed on the bottom right of the tablet. Personally, I have used Touchwiz before on my Galaxy S3, but I didn't like the feel. I have upgraded to a different launcher that allows for more customization to all screens. Android is highly adaptable and highly customizable, which is one of my number one reasons for choosing this tablet vs an ipad mini or the new Nexus 7.Feel:The body of the tablet is made of the same plastic and glass as the rest of the Samsung Galaxy flagship line. On a tablet of this size, it doesn't feel bad. The corners are nicely sculpted, the screen is slick and smooth. The S pen is tucked neatly away inside the lower right corner of the tablet, and comes out with a satisfying click when removed. It is nearly a bit too large to handle with one hand, but is large enough that typing is easy, even for someone with large fingers.Screen:The resolution of the screen is 1280x800 and at 189ppi it is quite a bit higher than the current generation ipad mini (163ppi), but significantly lower than the newest Nexus 7 (323ppi). There are some applications that look a bit rough, but the majority of those applications are optimized for phones, rather than tablets. While the Nexus 7 kills this tablet on resolution alone, it doesn't have an s-pen or any of the s-pen specific apps avaiable, so these are really two different animals.Speed:The speed and memory of this tablet are right on par with the rest of the tablets available in the coming months. It is fast, handles multiple processes with ease. I have noticed no slow down issues when watching video and using other apps at the same time.Battery Life:I have been getting several days out of the battery at a shot (depends on my daily usage). However I have wifi set to sleep when the display is off unless it is plugged into an outlet and charging. Usually I am seeing between 6-7hrs of screen on time before getting to about 10% battery. I leave display brightness set to auto, and smart stay is on.S-pen:The s-pen that is included with the device is much larger than those that come with the Note and Note 2 phones. It feels very good in your hand and is definitely usable by people with larger hands (me, being one of them). I still however have chosen to purchase a larger s-pen for comfort reasons when trying to sketch or take notes quickly.I am very happy with the Galaxy Note 8.0 overall. I would have rated it higher if there were more tablet optimized android apps available, a slightly higher screen resolution, and if the price were lower. At this time, the Note 8.0 is really the only android tablet of this size to offer the s-pen, and samsung knows that, so they charge for it. The experience of using the s-pen is in an entirely different world than using a capacitive stylus on any other device.

Reviews.Title: Returned the Galaxy 3 8.0 for this Note 8.0
Reviews.Author: J. Wong
Reviews.Content: I was very happy with the Galaxy Tab 8.0. So easy to hold and comfortable. It was by far one of my favorite computer/tablet purchases ever. However there was one thing that drove me nuts. Watching youtube videos going from landscape to portrait or vice versa the video would pause or stop each time. It made watching videos in your hand a big hassle.The Note 8.0 is certainly to me not as comfortable to hold but what can you do? Watching videos is important to me so I had to fork over extra money.I didnt give the Note 8.0 5 stars just cause of the comfort factor vs the Tab 8.0.

Reviews.Title: Surprisingly Great Product
Reviews.Author: Neal Johnson
Reviews.Content: This was my first non-Windows computer purchase.  I became a fan of the Android system when I purchased a Galaxy S3 last year.  I am very pleased.  I recently purchased an Asus Windows 8 tablet for my wife.  Now that I have a choice I find myself constantly going for the Galaxy Note 8.  I was angry when I saw the list price for the Samsung case at $49.  I felt that Samsung was exploiting it's unique size and newness by overcharging for a simple case.  Found a great 3rd market for $12.I purchased a 64 gb micro sd card to go with it and now I have lots of storage for movies and work.  I also find myself using the stylus more and more. I considered other tablets but the ability to add storage sold me.

Reviews.Title: Well worth the money! Fastest tablet I've ever had
Reviews.Author: sunshine
Reviews.Content: The Samsung galaxy note 8 is the best tablet I've ever owned! The note is fast, sleek, small, and powerful. The plastic back looks very sharp and holds up fine. Any worries that this tablet will easily break is just completely wrong.Apps- The note is powerful enough to play any app no problem. They run fast and never lag! I have had iron man 3, fast and furious 6, and Netflix all running at the same time and nothing shut down. On my iPad 3 this would have led to an app crash at the very least.Movies- While I don't usually watch movies on my tablets, the note has no problem playing them. I have Netflix, Hulu, and videos from Google Play on my Note. The note while not quite HD, is still a high quality resolution picture. Images are sharp and crisp on the note with appropriate shading. The ipad does have a slightly higher resolution screen (if that really is all that matters to you in a tablet then get an ipad). The sound quality is okay. The speakers are on the bottom back which I really didn't like, but are easily loud enough to hear without worry.SPen- Is very handy, great for taking notes or memos. It is easier than typing and much faster. the screen is sensitive and easily picks up the pen strokes taking down messages letter for letter without mistake.Browsing the web- incredibly easy to get information and do whatever on the web. Wifi speeds are fast, and has a very strong signal. Easily keeping 4 bars from long ranges (unlike my iPad 3).I love this tablet and easily recommend it over the ipad. While the ipad has a sharper image, it lacks power and runs much more sloppy than the note 8.0. The size, power, and price are perfect on the Note 8.0. The screen  is the perfect size for a tablet. And I highly recommend you get this tablet!

Reviews.Title: I am in Love!
Reviews.Author: Arin
Reviews.Content: What I've always hated about the i Phone is that it is a pain to punch letter by letter on the digital keyboard. I never want to write into anything on the web or for the Calendar. I am probably one of the last people that likes to "write" things down. So this note tablet is INCREDIBLE! It does everything that I want it to do. I am even writing this review on it which is taking about 25% of the time it would take me to pound it out with my fingertips! The write to text technology is amazing. I am using it for shopping lists, to do lists and to write better responses to emails when I don't have access to a computer. Average battery life ranges from 1-2 days with good usage. The other great thing is that you can fit it easily into a purse unlike the full size iPad. I know there are all the reviews out there about it being a "phablet" but I would never want to use the note 8 as a phone. I am glad it only has wi-fi so that I am not wanting to use it all the time which is not healthy. Recommended for those that like to write, the S-Pen is fabulous!!!

Reviews.Title: My Dream Tool
Reviews.Author: Scath
Reviews.Content: I'm a writer, one who finds she's more productive writing longhand rather than typing directly into a file. So I've been writing longhand, and then typing my work into a file which is A) time consuming, and B) double wear and tear on hands and wrists.Now I don't have to do both. =)With the S Pen, Dropbox, and MyScript Stylus app, my Note has become a writer's dream tool. I write, it converts to text directly into the story file I'm working on, and every time I hit save, it's uploaded to my Dropbox.That's all I wanted it for: a dedicated writing device. It's perfect for the job, not too big or heavy, and not so small that it's difficult to write on the screen.I do have a few songs loaded on it, so that I can listen to music while writing, and the sound's really good for such a device.The cons are few, and the main one would be all the dang pre-installed apps that you can't delete. I intensely dislike having stuff on my devices I'm never going to use, and would rather have the storage space free. However, I've grown accustomed to it on my phone, so I guess I'll do the same for my tablet.The other con is the size of the stylus. I realize it's made to fit in the tablet, but you'd think a tool meant for frequent usage would be designed to be more comfy to hold and use for long periods of time. It's not, so you may have to take frequent breaks to stretch your hand. The solution is to buy a "cover" that converts the stylus to regular pen size (which I've done).All in all, I'm extremely pleased with my purchase of this tablet, and am looking forward to using it for a long time.

Reviews.Title: 6-month usage review: Still best in the market for note taking
Reviews.Author: JY
Reviews.Content: I've been using this tablet for 6 months now mostly for taking notes in classes and meetings with an average use of a few hours a day.The accessories: a folio case with a stylus loop holder, anti glare screen protector, and a Wacom note stylus.  I have not rooted this or used any customized ROMs.Short review: After 6 mo, I still use this everyday for quite a few hours.  Great for note taking and pdf reading on the go.  However, those who intend to use this for hours of note taking and studying off of this should consider the 10.1 inch version, more screen real estate matters in this case.  The lack of quality accessory vendor partnership makes it harder to turn this into a full productivity work horse.Detailed review:The great things:- Compact and portable, much easier than carrying a 10.1 in tablet around- The stylus (the original and the Wacom one that I bought) work really well on the tablet.- Palm rejection is great on this. Though sometimes your hand might hit the "back" button on the lower right next to the home button.- I get about 6-7 hours of usage out of thisThe not so great things:- The screen resolution is not the sharpest out there, if you watch a lot of movies or need to have the best resolution, then this might not be for you. For casual users who focus mainly on taking notes and reading, I found this to be more than adequate.- Requires to have a high output charger.  The included charger is a 2.1A one, and this won't charge when you plug it into a computer.- Almost no big time accessory vendor partnership.  This is still a niche product, all the accessories like keyboards and such are from less known vendors. While these still work great, they add unnecessary bulk.  Zagg makes a folio keyboard for this tablet that is really good but makes it hard to use the tablet for writing and is way over priced.- The included stylus is great but a bit too small to write comfortably for an extended period of time (>20 min).  I bought a Wacom stylus and found it to be much better, and it also has an eraser on the back so you can just use it like an eraser on the tablet.Thoughts on taking notes:I got this tablet to reduce the paper clutter and also to be able to remember and organize all the little notes that I take.  This tablet does all that and then some. The only adjustment that I made was make sure not to press down too hard while writing.  When writing on paper, we tend to press the ballpoint down a bit to get the ink out, but on the tablet screen this isn't required.  Once you are adjusted to that, I find myself writing faster on the tablet than on paper.The big app on the tablet is the S Note.  My favorite feature is this "Recording" option in the app.  When you press the button, the app will record whatever your pen strokes are next.  This is fantastic for taking notes on equations or diagrams (ie those orgo reactions or physics equations) because when you hit replay, it will play back what you've written, stroke by stroke!  The downside about the app is that you can't read it easily out of the tablet. You have to manually export it as a pdf or png (image) file as the actual note file is proprietary and there aren't apps out there that can read it on a pc or mac easily.  Once you've exported, you also can't edit it.  What i find myself using more is the LectureNotes app, which is really good.  Same idea as the S Note, but you can export it more easily into Evernote.If you are in college or taking classes and intend on using your tablet more like a productivity machine throughout your daily schedule, I would actually recommend the 10.1 inch version.  I think the 8.0 is great for meeting notes and writing on the go, but when you are dealing with hours of lectures and really have to study off of a tablet, the larger dimensions do make sense.  It is also easier to do multi window on a larger screen.  After 6 months of using this, I still find it to be fast and responsive.  The screen does heat up a bit if you are charging and using it at the same time.  I also suggest on getting a Wacom stylus, like the one here (http://www.amazon.com/Samsung-Galaxy-S-Pen-Stylus-Eraser/dp/B009QW3SGQ/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid;=1393774422&sr;=8-6&keywords;=wacom+galaxy+note+stylus).  The bigger size actually makes it a lot easier to write with.My only gripe is that there aren't many quality, thin-profiled keyboard cases for this that are reasonably priced.  Because of the lack of quality accessory vendor support, I'm taking a star away in the rating.  For high profile products like this, I take into account of how the accessory support is when considering the final rating.

Reviews.Title: I love this little tablet
Reviews.Author: Martha A
Reviews.Content: I own an iPad 1st gen and recieved this as a birthday present. After long and extensive research, I thought this tablet would be the perfect tablet for my school needs. I already own and iPhone 5s, so buying another iPad just seemed like having a giant version of my phone. After playing with my new tablet I can only think of two real issues with the tablet.Pros:-Perfect purse size tablet-Small and light-S-pen is an amazing feature-Quick response time-great screen resolution-samsung sends emails about different features supported by the note 8Cons:-it is 16gb before all the preinstalled apps provided by samsung. After realizing that the approximately free 9gb would not be enough space for me, I invested in a 32gb sd card. If considering this tablet, the sd card is a much needed accessory.-certain cases distort s-pen functionality. The resolution to this problem is to look for cases that do not have a magnet in the design.Honestly, I'm happy I recieved this tablet and I would recommend this tablet to others. However, do your own research before buying an expensive product like this. The Note 10.1 2014 edition was just released before I bought this one, but I liked the size of this one over the Note 10.1.

Reviews.Title: PERFECT Tablet!
Reviews.Author: isabelle solus
Reviews.Content: If there’s only one thing I could say about this tablet, I’d say it’s the perfect device for me! What I personally love the most about the Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 is the integrated S Pen, which comes with features, such as note-taking and handwriting-to-text, unique to this tablet that make it perfect for students. The fact that there’s many ways to personalize the home screens also attracted me to this tablet. I love the retro-looking appearance of this tablet, and its 8 inches makes it portable, perfect to fit in the palm of my hand! (The additional inch compared to the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 7-inch really makes a difference. It's perfect if your not looking for the size and cost of a larger tablet like the Samsung Galaxy Note Tablet 10.1) The Samsung Galaxy Note Tablet is an efficient productivity tablet. Along with the S pen, It comes with a variety of other useful features, like the multi-window function that allows two apps to be open at once side-by-side (which is awesome to me);an infrared blaster, which can have the device as a remote control to any tv; and the eye sensor, which keeps the screen on as long as you’re looking at it. I praise this device’s great battery life, fast web browser speed, high video and speaker quality, 16GB storage, and decent front and rear camera. The Samsung Galaxy Note Tablet comes in an affordable $300 to $400 price range, yet I feel it is slightly overpriced for a mini tablet, but this tablet is worth it, especially with the inclusion of the S Pen and $400 worth of “Galaxy Perks” that come with purchase of this Galaxy device! The Samsung Galaxy Note is the perfect balance of work/school and fun. I highly recommend this tablet to anyone the S Pen stands out to and the avid note-taker, reader, and drawer. If the S Pen isn't for you I'd consider the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8.0, ipad mini, or the Google Nexus 7 if your looking for a similar product.I had it for 10 days already and I absolutely love my awesome new tablet! It is everything I hoped for!

Reviews.Title: Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0
Reviews.Author: S. Eaton
Reviews.Content: Greetings All!I have the Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 and i love it. I take it in my purse everywhere.I also use my 64gb sandisk sd card from my Galaxy Note 10.1 in it with no problems, watch movies from card and everything else.You will not be disappointed with this tablet.I barely use a computer anymore.I rooted mine so i could use the multiwindows app in the play store to turn all my apps into multiwindow apps.You can see how to do this on YouTube and get the app from playstore or maybe even Amazon apps has it.Enjoy The Day!

Reviews.Title: THIS is the right size!
Reviews.Author: Nick Vanmatre "nickv"
Reviews.Content: The Samsung 8 inch NOTE IS the correct size for me and other folks that may not have good eyes or good gripping hands and that want to use the NOTE for lots of book reading.  While I have a Kindle Paperwhite and love it, the NOTE 8 has expanded my ability to enjoy all that is available on the internet. It is light, a good large screen but not too large: therefore making it too heavy.As an older guy with poor hearing, I actually can hear this NOTE while wearing my hearing aids.  Many devices I can not hear at all even if I am wearing the hearing aids.I fell in love with this device within minutes of turning it on.  I sent back the new Samsung 8 inch TAB without even opening it. Ok, I did buy both of them on the same day and received them on the same day.  I was planning on returning one of them.  No contest for me; the NOTE takes the cake.  Now, got to go read a bit....

Reviews.Title: LOVE this Tablet!!
Reviews.Author: Lisa Crooke
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love this tablet.  The best thing about it is the size.  the 10 inch tablets are too big and the 7 inch tablets feel too small.  Feels like the size of a small book in your palm.  The resolution of the screen is great!  I have not experienced any of the "leaking" that others have experienced.  The best part is the stylus!!  I can use the stylus to create notes, emails, in free hand and the samsung does an excellent job of converting to text.... no more fat fingering the keys on the key board.  Also love that you can do free hand drawing on this.  The power is great..... the device lasts a good long while on one charge.  So glad I waited for this tablet.  Am LOVING it!

Reviews.Title: Great tablet
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I bought my Note 8 at Best Buy the day it came out.  I have been very happy with it.  I bought the additional stylus with a pen holder which works outstanding (you do have to remove the stylus that cam with the note to activate the microswitch.  I also KHomo case which folds back and has a hand hold on the back.  Perfect for holding in one hand a taking notes.  I user the OfficeSuite 7 Pro App, for MS office compatibility, Evernote (which I use most often), and write, for jotting down quick notes.  I have not been disappointed at all with the Note 8!

Reviews.Title: Sweet!
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: I went from the Nexus 7 to the Samsung Note, and overall I'm very happy with it. The handwriting recognition is not as good as I'd hoped it would be.  But I thick thuds' Moby atrauiy issue for me more than the tablet. That sentence was uncorrected interpretation of what I wrote, which was: But I think that's a training issue for me more than the tablet. Other than that- the Screen display is very nice, performance is excellent and battery life seems to be good. It also charges much faster than the Nexus 7.I wrote this entire review with the S pen using handwriting recognition.

Reviews.Title: Ideal for nearly Everyone
Reviews.Author: Jeff
Reviews.Content: Bringing back the stylus of old resitive touchscreen technology has come with ridicule, but critics could not be more wrong. Combining technology of old with todays technological advancements offers a new valuable feature set that sets this tablet apart from the mainstream. With so many tablets offering virtually the same real world performace and feature set, when one comes out with a unique feature set it makes the decision of which to purchase much easier. As long as you know what that feature set has to offer you.PROS:The processor and memory allows you to breeze through menus and execute any operation to include any app currently available on the market without a hiccup. The screen is bright and clear with no notable differences side by side with my daughter's iPad Mini. Battery life is on par of all the others easily getting through a heavy days work without charge. However, these are not the features that should draw you toward this tablet as many have these same bragging rights at a smaller price. The precise control of the Wacom's 'S' pen technology is its defining feature. You can truly use this to replace pen and paper when taking notes during a lecture or meeting. Try the same thing with your finger or fat tipped touch capacitive stylus and you will quickly be back to a pen and paper after your notes end up looking worst than a 5 year old writing with a crayon. Refining pictures on photoshop is quicker than on a computer with a mouse and again offers the precision unmatched by any other (non-penabled) tablets. The same thing obviously holds true for artists or doodlers when using applications like Sketchbook plus adding the utility of pressure sensitivity for accurate shading without having to contstantly adjust through the menu. In addition to the 'S' pen, the IR sensor is more useful than I had imagined. I easily added all my TVs,  Bluray players, projector, receivers organized by room even my 15 year old Aiwa system. Granted the app could be a little better by adding easier access to more controls for each device but does well enough to bypass buying a $100+ Logitech remote.CONS:Samsung fanatics ardently back the use of plastic to encase their premium devices, but the look and feel simply does not match the quality exuded by Apple products or Asus's infinity tablets. Although I would love for Samsung to take note and offer a premium casing to match the rest of the device, adding a quality case easily remedies this minor complaint.OVERALL:Anyone who wants to use a tablet for everything from an powerful productivity tool at work or school to taking full advantage of art and photo apps should look no further than this or possibly a Note 10.1. Personally, I have found the 8.0 tablet as easily useful as 10 inchers with better form factor to use on the go, but those who plan on using it for more for graphical design might want the extra real estate at the cost of resolution. If you have no interest in jotting notes, utilizing photo or art apps then save money and get a Nexus 7 or one of the other countless counterparts with similar features, otherwise look no further as the price of Note 8.0 is easily justified

Reviews.Title: Best 8" Tablet For Artists
Reviews.Author: Raniel Bambasi
Reviews.Content: So to start off, I do think that the $399 price tag is a bit much, which is why I'm giving it four stars, but besides that, this tablet is pretty darn great. I'm a painter/illustrator and while I wouldn't use this for anything official (unless it's my last resort), this does make for a great on-the-go digital sketchbook. The S-Pen is accurate enough that drawing on it is almost as accurate as writing with a physical pen and paper. There's still a tiny TINY bit of lag if you're used to Wacom tablets but it's probably not noticeable to most people, and out of all the Android tablets I've tried this has been THE most accurate. It won't replace a Wacom Cintiq but as I mentioned, is great for sketching, best coupled with Autodesk apps. The S-Note app is great but it's pretty limited as an actual drawing or painting program.Other features that can be useful for artists would be the Multi-Window feature. I haven't used it much as of now but I can see it becoming very useful when researching and note taking. Another one would be the aNote HD app. I wish they renamed it because it sounds like an amateur app but it's a great organizer. So if you're the type that has a lot of ideas, thoughts, notes and events that you need to document, this app would make things easier for you. It's pretty detailed as well, so you can make sure that all your entries are neatly organized and properly labeled in a fashionable manner. The S-Note has the same, though more S-Pen dependent features, and as far as I can remember, both the aNote and S-Note can work together, so that's handy.As far as drawbacks, I know it sounds odd but the system sounds are very limited. For example, the system sounds for pressing buttons, locking and unlocking are all water-drop themed. I'm not sure why Samsung had to pick such a specific sound instead of a sound that has mass appeal. You can't even change it to something else, you either have it on or off, which is a bummer if you want a more professional sounding tablet, but I digress. The screen does get smudged easier than say, a Nexus 7 but I guess that can be countered by buying a screen protector or having a handy tablet-friendly cloth wipe.Another drawback is that even though the system is marketed as 16gb, I only have 9gb of available memory. I've used less than a gig of memory so far and it's disappointing that the system is close to being full - by today's typical memory consumption standards. I know that companies always market devices at a certain amount only to find that a few gigs have been removed when you get the device, but 9gb from 16gb is a bit absurd. So just a warning, you should buy an SD card if you need more than that. You technically do get a 50gb Dropbox account - though it has yet to appear on my account, might have to activate it? - and have the ability to access your Google Drive, assuming you have one, which technically gives you around an extra 65gb if you're connected to the internet, but if you want memory on the go, I suggest just buying a memory card if you can.Overall I do love this device. I wish it was cheaper, but whatever. If you're an artist and looking for a good tablet to draw on, you can't really beat the Note 8.0. As far as I know, Wacom themselves provide the pressure sensitive technology so you're in good hands. I might trade it in or sell it when the REAL Wacom tablet comes out, but who knows when that will be. In the mean time, this will do the job.PS, If you're debating between the 10.1 and the 8.0 and size isn't an issue, I recommend the 8.0 because the 10.1's screen isn't as responsive compared to the 8.0. The only thing that can beat the 8.0 in the near future would be the upcoming Samsung ATIV tablets which also sports the S-Pen, but those are more closer to being computers than tablets. So basically if you like the 8" size and would need the S-Pen functionality, it's worth the money.

Reviews.Title: One thing to note about movies on this tablet...
Reviews.Author: JTS
Reviews.Content: From the beginning of my tablet search I was dead set on purchasing an iPad mini.  I have an iphone, an ipod classic, ipod touch and an ipod shuffle and have had good experiences with Apple products and didn't see any reason not to get an Apple tablet.  I didn't like the regular iPad due to size and weight so the mini was in my sights.  However, the one thing that held me back was the screen resolution of the iPad mini and the fact that Apple would likely release an improved mini 2 with better resolution and better processor.  I'm not saying that the current mini screen and processor is bad but knowing that it could be a lot better kept me from purchasing it.  So I decided to wait for the mini 2...and so I waited...and waited and then something interesting happened.  I decided to poke my foot outside of the Apple universe and see what other tablets were on the market and I came across some articles about the Samsung Note 8 and what intrigued me was the S pen.  This is my first tablet purchase and I wanted something that I could use for work in addition to home and the S pen seemed like a great feature.  I've always wanted to reduce all the paper clutter around my desk and having all my notes electronic was very appealing.  When I tried the Note 8 out at a local Best Buy, I was sold.  A lot of the key features and highlights have already been described in previous reviews so no need to repeat them here.  My primary use for the tablet is for note taking, productivity tasks, reading ebooks, and surfing the net (checking emails, news, stocks).  Occasionally, I would use it to play some games and watch movies to kill time if I was traveling.  After a couple of weeks of usage I can say that I am happy with my purchase with a drawback that, in my opinion, keeps this from being a 5 star tablet.The drawback is trying to get movies onto the Note 8 without having to shell out additional $$ to purchase the movie in the Google Play store.  I have numerous blu ray discs that come with a digital copy of the movie.  Therefore, I can't justify shelling out another $15 to buy the android version of the movie.  I have found in a lot of cases the blu ray digital copy can be accessed either through Ultraviolet streaming which can be done via a Flixster app or a copy can be downloaded to a phone or tablet IF you have iTunes.  Right off the bat, I know that I will not be able to copy a digital movie from iTunes to an Android tablet.  So there doesn't seem to be a way to get those digital movies onto the Note 8.  On the other hand it's a cinch to move them onto an Apple phone or tablet with iTunes.  So my next option was to see if I can stream the movie via Ultraviolet/Flixster, which is not my first choice because its a wi-fi only tablet.  The problem is Flixster will not allow you to stream Ultraviolet movies if you have a rooted device.  Which is all well and good if you don't root your device but if you don't root your device then you can't have Flash Player running when you browse the web.  In my opinion, Flash makes the web experience better and that's why my device is rooted.  To go through the process of unrooting, and then streaming and then re-rooting seems like an inconvenience. I have Amazon Prime so I tried to stream movies from Prime but to my dismay I could not find the Amazon Instant Video app in the Google Play store.  They have it for the iTunes App store but not for Android.  What???  At the end of the day, this drawback was enough to prevent me from giving this product a perfect score of 5 stars primarily because it seems like an iPad would have less roadblocks to overcome when compared to the Note 8 in order to copy or play movies.  Again, this is not to say that the Note 8 is a bad product, the S pen is terrific, the size is perfect, the speed is top notch...its just my experience thus far with trying to use it for movies has been less than great.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing in quality, features, battery, and service
Reviews.Author: Alastair J. Schoen
Reviews.Content: When I first got my hands on the Note about 10 weeks ago I was pretty excited and having a great time with it. The screen, initial battery life, s-pen, and speed of the tablet were great. I come from an all-apple background but have recently switched to Android because of the greater freedom they allow. The first problem that was apparent was actually getting the benefits that the tablet purports to come with such as the Google Play credit. It took me two weeks of back and forth with Samsung to get the credit applied to my google account. A problem, should you look at their facebook support page, seems to be very widely experienced. Disappointing but nonetheless handled and now out of the way. Reckoned it was time for me to enjoy my tablet.I love the screen, I think 8 inches is just the best size for reading coupled with an excellent screen. The ergonomics are great even wrapped in a case, good weight and an acceptable camera. The tablet is also quite good in power, I play Shadowgun (3D FPS) and it looks great and runs smooth.The S-Pen is pretty sweet and enjoyable as a method of input combined with the one-hand ergonomics of the tablet. Nice for scribbling, drawing, and text input. However, according to the adverts I assumed I could use the pen to cut out imagery from a variety of things, like Googlemaps for example, and pull it into an email or note-program and annotate it easily. Turns out this isn't the case at all. Most programs, including the note programs included in the note won't allow the s-pen cut-out images to be imported into them. aNote HD allows it somewhat, but image resolution is ridiculously grainy and illegible if it contains text. I've watched the instructive videos on youtube but they have not illuminated anything new that would allow this. Comments are completely welcome on this front.QUALITY PROBLEMS ARE KILLING THIS FOR MEHowever, within 1 month, and without any drops or rough handling of the tablet (I keep it in a case at all times), a hairline crack starting forming on the top bezel, just above the Samsung logo. I immediately contacted Samsung through their facebook support page but never received a response. Within another week the crack had stretched across the whole top bezel and another one appeared on the upper side of the power button on the side bezel. I again used the facebook page as well as the direct service support on Samsung's website. To this day I have not received any response to my problems. Not only is the build quality lacking on the tablet, but non-existent customer service has radically changed my perception of Samsung's products for the worse.Furthermore, I purchased the tablet as a computer substitute for graduate school and the Note 8.0's long battery life was one of the primary determinants for purchase. However, unlike the first several weeks of 11 hours, the battery life has dropped by hours and I'm lucky if I get 7 with moderate use and conservative power-settings. If I turn on the Wifi and surf, it may can drop another few hours. Moreover, the battery will often drop very rapidly and have had the tablet suddenly shutdown showing 0% life without any warning (Typically a warning pops at 15 & 5%). When the tablet is around 35% range, it can hit zero within 30 minutes. Charging is also showing irregularity, more than once I have left it to charge overnight, heard the affirmative charging sound, and wake to find it at 0% despite having been 30-40% when I plugged it in (Furthermore I turned it off while charging).Bizarre, and I would assume this tablet is clearly defective but I have so far failed to get anyone at Samsung to pay attention to me. I thought Samsung was the top of the heap in terms of Android products, especially for a tablet that's well-more expensive than its competition. Despite my disagreements with Apple's accessibility, I'm thinking perhaps the hardware and software quality trade-off may not be worth it.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet if its in the $200 range
Reviews.Author: keo "Get the best deal, then get disappointed...
Reviews.Content: This is Excellent for the price.  I've owned one for close to a year, and its the perfect balance between a 5" and 10".  Most people won't be happy with the resolution of the screen, but I think its just fine especially for taking notes.  Speed is fine for browsing and writing, although at times it can have trouble with intense games. I've owned the new Note 10.1 2014 version, and the Note 2, and I actually enjoy the Note 8.0 much better (to each their own) than either of them.  Yes the 10.1 2014 version has a nicer screen and higher specs, but if you're using this tablet for Note taking or drawing, higher everything also meant draining the battery quickly.  I just shut off the Wi-fi, turn down the screen to 35-50%, and I'm set for hours in school. Also, although the new S-note has nice new shiny excellent features, there is obvious lag in the pen, and you can't use detailed erasing when drawing like the note 8.0.  In erase mode, once you touch the current piece you have written, the eraser will remove EVERYTHING.  There are no settings to remove this.  The Note 8.0 uses very detailed erasing, and writing is very smooth.For those that are wondering if the Note 8.0 is good for taking notes at school, I'd say yes.  I've used it through 3 hour classes no problem,  and its easy to write and erase things during class.  Once I hit 60-70%, I attach a portable battery to it and juice it back to 100%.  Place the tablet in landscape, and its easy to write.  Pinch to zoom for detailed writing and you can pan around the screen using the same two fingers while dragging them along to the spots you'd like to view (at times it feels like an old type writer when pulling the page back to the beginning of the next line).  Its great for kids to practice their ABC's, just be sure to properly protect it and keep an eye on the S-pen.S-note is decent, but I prefer using the app Lecture Notes.  It costs $5, but well worth the cost if you like to customize your note taking and download PDF's to write over.  I sometimes download Coloring Book PDF's for my niece to draw on and save myself from buying books and crayons.  Its also great when a professor emails PDF's for class because you can highlight important information.  I'd sometimes "white out" terms, study the content, then remove the "white out" portions to check if I was correct on the term.  Its and excellent tool.In the end, its all about personal preference.  I like the balance of an 8" tablet, vs bigger or smaller versions.  I think I spent too much money at the time I purchased this gadget, but if the tablet is in the $200 range, I'd say its worth every penny.  Spend time with it, and you'll be very happy with this device.

Reviews.Title: Love it, use it every day
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Pros: Small form factor, long battery life, good suite of pre-installed programs, SD-card up-gradable, stylus works perfectly, lightweight, recent OS can run any Android apps (as of this writing), IR blaster for remote control capability, great stylus shortcuts, easy screen captures, practically anything can be "shared" to other apps (like Gmail, Evernote, Dropbox, etc.), bright and clear screen, very customizable interface, charges pretty quickly, makes a good e-Reader, usable for personal and professional tasks.Cons: Templates in S-Note are very difficult to create and customize; takes some tech know-how.  It's slow to notify you of things you already knew (tells you that you plugged in headphones several minutes after the fact while watching a movie, for example). Battery is not really replaceable by the user without taking it apart. The Kit Kat Android OS hasn't been pushed out to it yet (as best I can tell).Recommending tablets is a funny business; we all use them for different things. I am comfortable with Mac, Windows, Android, and iOS, so I can adapt. If you're an iPad-only person, this will take some time to get used to. If you're a Microsoft person, same thing. I think it's very intuitive though, and love all the shortcuts for opening apps, taking screenshots and partial screen captures, taking/editing photos on the fly, etc.  If it weren't for just a couple apps that are iPad-only, I'd switch to this device exclusively.I do a good amount of handwriting on my tablet, so the size is becoming a limitation for me personally. Will probably upgrade to the new 12" Note Pro that was just released so I have more space to write naturally. But if you're looking for a good tablet in the 7-8" range, this one is highly recommended. I can't think of much I would suggest to the manufacturer for new features, other than a few bug fixes here or there.BTW, I bought mine refurbished and haven't had a single issue with it.

Reviews.Title: MHL Technology Sucks
Reviews.Author: Big C
Reviews.Content: I love my Note 8. It's fast, productive and stylish, You can read all the accolades by other reviewers. My review is focused on the Mobile High-Definition Link (MHL) connection. Instead of having a mcro-HDMI it has the MHL. This means I have to connect a MHL adapter to my device, a hdmi cable from the adapter to the laptop, PC or TV (some adapter have built-in HDMI cable), and connect my power adapter from a power source to my MHL adapter. The purpose of the power source is to power the device since HD video can consume a lot of battery. The problem is that I have all these cables hanging from my device. I tried giving a presentation in my class and it was so cumbersome and restrictive because of the length of my power cable. Also, I was concerned about the weight of all the cables on my MHL port. I don't want the charging port on my device to become loose because of these cables hanging off of it.My Kindle HD 7' has a micro HDMI connection. I connect my 6ft micro HDMI to HDMI cable between the device and my laptop/ PC or TV and give seamless presentations, or watch Prime, Netflix, Youtube, etc without a hitch. With the Note 8 it is cumbersome because of the added power source. I have returned to using my Fire HD for giving presentations in professional settings instead of the Note 8.I would give the Note 8 a solid 4 stars (even 4.5 stars) if it wasn't for this issue. You would think that Samsung would have thought about this if it wanted to pitch the Note 8 towards students and professionals. As stated, love my Note 8 except for the MHL and giving presentations or watching video on my HDTV.

Reviews.Title: Samsung Galaxy Note 8 is perfect.
Reviews.Author: Kaywinnit
Reviews.Content: I'm already logged in to order something else so I thought I'd rate my GN8.  I love it.  I'm normally an early adopter but held out for years and years through Palm Pilots and PDAs and smartphones and various iPads and waited for the perfect thing - this.  The s-pen is perfect, I use it for writing (amazing hand writing recognition) and drawing (I use PS Touch and ArtFlow, both excellent).  I stream video from my PC, and seamless sync my calendar and email.  It's small enough to tuck in my bag and large enough to be usable.  Sometimes (when drawing) I wonder if I should have chosen the Note 10.0, but in balance this size is the best for me. After some research I ordered the perfect screen protector, MiniGuard by MiniSuit,which does not interfere with the S-pen, and got a sweet case with a swivel stand for almost nothing from the same place (through Amazon).I could go on but suffice to say there is nothing I do not like about my Galaxy Note 8; it is worth every penny.

Reviews.Content: I purchased SGN8 three months ago after reviewing and trying other tablets.  I believe this is the best small tablet out there... Consumer Reports has it No 1...Prior to purchasing I bought S4, which,  like the  SGN8 run on the latest Android os.. I use this in business and also personally.. This tablet has every feature important to me..  I am so glad that I got the 8 instead of the 10...I am holding this in one hand and typing with the other... Reviews.Content: It is very convenient.I can put it in my purse.the memory is expandable. It is not heavy. I had the very first galaxy tab 10.0 and I love that one but the 8.0 note does everything the big does and more.The battery life is really good.

Reviews.Title: Perfect Size, Excellent Performance
Reviews.Author: BW
Reviews.Content: I decided to pay the extra $80 for the Note 8.0 instead of getting the Tab 3 8 inch and I am glad I did (Heck I spend $80 on lunch in a single week sometimes)!  The quad core (instead of dual core) and extra RAM (2 Gig vs 1.5 Gig) is well worth the performance gains.  I added a 64 gig microSD card and I have enough storage space to last me a very long time.  The S Pen of course is a nice bonus.  If you're deciding between these two tablets, think no more and get the Note 8.0, you'll be glad you did.  Samsung makes the best tablets bar none.  iPad?  No thanks.

Reviews.Title: Best Tablet of 2013!
Reviews.Author: Joe
Reviews.Content: Since I bought an Android 4.0 Media Player back in 2011, I always wanted a high end tablet but didn't have the money. The media player is great on the go but has drawbacks such as poor battery life, four inch screen, and low specs. 1 GHz processor and 486 MB RAM. My mom opted to buy one for me as I didn't have the money to afford one.Today I found at Staples they were selling it for $299.99! But I went over to Best Buy and they price matched Staples as my mom was buying other items from there. I wanted the black color, instead of white and brown was unavailable. Originally I wanted to buy the Google 7 32 GB but passed on it. I read average reviews online and spoke to people who didn't like using it. Also ASUS has poor customer service in helping and fixing problems.When I came home, I opened the brown box and began to use it. Very easy to use. Thankfully Samsung still uses Micro SD cards. The tablet loads up immediately as well as the Micro SD card. The sound is fantastic! If you think two small speakers can't produce great sound, think again! I didn't have to raise the volume way up. I still have it on low and the sound is loud. Easy to use interface. Long battery life as long as you don't run games and video's all the time. I like to browse the internet quickly. But this is thanks to the 1.6 GHz Quad-Core Processor with 2 GB of RAM.My family has owned Samsung products for many years. We never had problems with any of them. TV's, camera's, Refrigerator, and now our first tablet. Will will continue to buy Samsung.

Reviews.Title: Quick, Very Responsive and Great Resolution
Reviews.Author: Frank Austin
Reviews.Content: I was somewhat hesitant to purchase a Tablet and did much research before I pulled the trigger on this purchase. I am happy that I did, it has more features than I counted on and the convenience of a tablet along with a screen big enough to see everything is great. The price is a bit high but I enjoy the ability to expand the memory to 64gb.

Reviews.Title: Best tablet for college

Reviews.Content: I love the Note 8.0, it is great for college. It is the right size, easy to carry and use. The stylus is great, I do a lot of handwriting with it. Would highly recommend it if you are looking for a good college tablet, or for recreational uses.

Reviews.Title: Love this tablet

Reviews.Content: I never write reviews but I had to. This tablet is the greatest invention ever. I can use it for work, personal, netflix, etc. The battery life is great and the pen is perfect for writing. I use it everyday it fits in my purse and can hold more memory.
