Reviews.Title: Battery life and overall performance leaves something to be desired
Reviews.Author: Alex
Reviews.Content: I use my note 8 mainly for work, at which I take a lot of notes.  I really enjoy the writing and pen feature of the device, but the battery life and the overall performance of the device makes me jealous of others that are at work who mainly have ipads or ipad mini's.  The overall user experience is a bit choppy.  Some apps that exist on both ipad and android tablets work smoother and faster on my colleagues' ipads (accessing hospital electronic medical records), and there just seems to be more support for the ipad versions of things than android.  This isn't a knock on all things android.  I like my device and plan to continue to purchase android devices (probably beyond Samsung now).  I just wish this device were snappier and the battery performance were better.  To give an example of the battery being poor, I've once unplugged my device at 6am after charging overnight, and by 10am, the battery was in the red after using the pen to write some notes for about 2 hours at 50% brightness.  It's a weird issue because it doesn't always happen, but does occur occasionally.The overall feel that I'm getting with this device is like when I first bought a Galaxy S1 (Verizon Fascinate) and felt that it lagged behind the iphone version at that time but after upgrading to the Galaxy S3, the device felt much improved and much more on-par with the iphone version at the time of the S3 release.

Reviews.Title: Absolutely no complaints

Reviews.Content: I am not a power user by any means, but this tablet is amazing. It is plenty powerful enough for my purposes - browsing the internet, watching youtube, listening to music while multitasking, all that jazz. Samsung's software also blows away that of any other smart device I've used. The full-fledged toolbar in the notification drawer is a godsend and makes multitasking very easy. I love the stylus to death. I would never purchase a tablet without a feature like the S-pen after being spoiled by it. The tablet is a little inconsistent on the precision of tapping with the pen - usually it taps right where you want it to, but sometimes it is a pain. At any rate, the pen draws very smoothly. My only complaint is I wish the Multi-Window feature supported more apps. Not even Google Drive is supported, which is a huge bummer for me since I use that app more than most. Hopefully in the near future Drive and Firefox will join the list of apps supported.

Reviews.Title: I Bought This Tablet Twice, Unreliable At Best
Reviews.Author: M. Southakakoumar
Reviews.Content: Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice shame on me. I design apps for a living and I bought the Samsung Galaxy Note 8 Tablet as a test device because so much of my negative feedback stems from this model. After unboxing the device, I initially had no idea what users were complaining about. The hardware is solid and beautiful and everything works as promised.Of course, this honeymoon period was short lived and now I cringe everytime I pick up this device. There are things that work fine on other Android Tablets that just simply defy explanations on the Samsung Galaxy 8.BLOATWARE:I should have known better but, true to form I too started to experience the same issues with Samsung that my users were experiencing. First, the sheer volume of Samsung "bloatware" that ships with the tablet is amazing. These are Samsung branded apps that take up storage space on your device — that you might never use. Granted SOME of the apps are useful but most just take up space. It is as if Samsung doesn't realize there's a whole Google Play store that users can access anytime they need a new app. Yes, there is a micro SD port that allows me to expand my storage capacity but, it'd be nice if Samsung just allowed users to delete all of it's bloatware if the user doesnt use them. Period. (Note that this type of behavior is not isolated to Samsung. Many device manufacturers -- from HTC to the Carriers do the same thing.)FIRMWARE and SOFTWARE (OPERATING SYSTEM) UPDATES:Unlike Google Nexus Devices, the Galaxy Note 8.0 is a slave to the device manufacturer. What this means is, if Google releases a new update to their Android software — you can't just download it and experience the benefits right away. You have to wait until Samsung releases their own version of the update before you have access to it on your Samsung device. Most of the time, its because they have to test their own "bloatware" to see if it works on the new update. If it doesn't they need to retool their apps BEFORE they release the updates. If you don't use Samsung's bloatware apps, this can be more than frustrating.(Sure you can 'root' the device and override this issue — but, if you bought this to experience how most people would use the device, then rooting it defeats the whole purpose of using it as a test device.)CUSTOMER SERVICE is ABOMIDABLE:You may, overtime (for me it was within 90 days) start experiencing problems where your tablet starts to crash incessantly (you'll see the dreaded "Unfortunately Cloud Agent Has Stopped" message.) When you get online with Customer Service they will run you through a script (this is true for most Customer Service centers) as they try to diagnose just what is wrong with your device as well as what they can do to fix your problem(s).However, if you're an experienced Android user, you've most likely already gone online and done your due diligence and searched through user forums and found a bevy of unhappy Samsung Galaxy Note 8 owners with the same complaints/issues that you're experiencing. Most likely that means you've already updated your software, already power cycled (turn it off and then on again), completed a factory reset and a myriad of other quick fixes on your customer service representative's script.Having done all of the above, THIS is when your customer service rep starts grasping at straws to explain why your device may be misbehaving (phantom touches, screen lock-ups, crashes). And the solutions flung out at you range from blaming the magnets in your device case (which by the way is a SAMSUNG branded case specifically for the Galaxy Note 8) to blaming the micro-SD card (Im using a SanDisk Ultra) to telling you to delete all your apps and start from scratch (not a desirable process).MAYBE ITs A FLUKEHaving exhausted most of my patience, I decided (foolishly) that maybe my device was a lemon. One built on the last shift of the last day of the work week. These things happen. SO I bought a second Samsung Galaxy Note 8 — this time from an actual bricks and mortar retailer (BestBuy) — and just like my previous experience, it was great out of the box but, performance would start to lag in just a matter of days. It didnt matter that I killed all uneccessary tasks, was running only one app at a time, had RAM to spare, 10+ GB of open storage (more if you factor in the SD card), or even limited the specific apps I downloaded — the NEW Samsung Tablet acted much like it's twin I purchased online.Keep in mind Im not running anything out of the ordinary on these tablets, Im just using my Bank's Bill Pay app, Readability, Facebook, Twitter, Mint, DropBox, Evernote, IMDB, Hulu+, Netflix, HBO Go, the Google Apps Suite (Play, Google+, HangOuts, Chrome etc.)RESULTS MAY VARYYet from the other reviews you read here, you'll see some people are having a grand time and flawless performance with their Samsung Galaxy Note 8 -- so your results may vary. But for me personally, the Nexus devices work best — the Samsungs are too tempermental for my taste. When they work, they're a joy to use. When they dont work, I feel like flinging it across the room.

Reviews.Title: So close...
Reviews.Author: bechle "memento mori"
Reviews.Content: In short, if you like the Galaxy Note 2 phone you will like the construction of this device.  I found it well built, light, speedy and a very nice device.However, I'm going back to my Nook HD+ while I wait for a similar device with a better resolution.  After having using a retina iPad, a Nook HD+ and the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 1280x800 or lower just doesn't cut it anymore.  I've got used to reading a book where you can't see any jaggedness to the fonts.  There is a setting to enhance the fonts a little in the Samsung display options, but it's not the same.I've put mine up for sale.  Now don't get me wrong, it's a great device I guess I've just become a resolution snob.  :-)P.S.  If you register at Samsung you are supposed to get a $25 Google Store credit.  Do a Google for "samsung galaxy note 8 perks $25 credit."  I tried to register but it doesn't seem to be functional yet, but don't miss out on your free $25 of apps/books/movies,etc.EDIT:  Samsung is still having some issues with the $25 Play Credit registration, but they'll get it figured out.  Someone made a comment about the Nook HD+ I must comment on; yep, it's only a great device if you sideload Google Play store on it.  Anyway, back to the Note 8!  It's really growing on me.  It has one of the best touch screens I've ever used, responsive, very smooth and really a pleasure to use.  It's run every game and app I've thrown at it, and after playing with the spen a bit more it definitely is nice to have.  Cool to pull it out and have a note auto open and then just jot something down.  I still wish the screen were a little better, but it's really a decent screen.  I would HIGHLY recommend this over the iPad mini, at least until Apple replaces the abominable 1024x768 screen in it.

Reviews.Content: I really like the Note 8 because it's more compact than my Note 10.1, but I'm returning it due to the low quality of the front facing camera. I do a lot of recording from my tablet and I take a lot of pictures as well using my front facing camera. The Note 8 front facing camera is only 1.3mp, but the Note 10.1 comes with a 1.9mp front facing camera. At first I was going to return my 10.1 when I ordered this one, but I'm glad that I waited. All in all this a very nice tablet, but for $400 I really think the front facing camera should have been better. My little sister has a Galaxy 3 phone and her front facing camera is the same quality as the 10.1, so I know the quality of the Note 8 front facing camera could have been the same or even better. I wish I could keep both, but I'm a unemployed student, so I have to go with what works for me and that's the Note 10.1. Most people don't use it for the camera features, so i would definitely recommend it for all the other features that it offers.

Reviews.Title: Lack of Updates
Reviews.Author: Eric J Roberts
Reviews.Content: The tablet itself works great and the S Pen is pretty accurate but hard to hold.  My biggest complaint about the tablet is my main complaint for all android devices.  They rarely get updated to new versions of the OS.  This one is already 2 versions out of date since it still only supports Jelly Bean.  Samsung only releases updates for their devices if it adds a feature that benefits them such as to support their worthless Galaxy Gear Watch.  My other complaint is each model has a different interface.  Makes using them complicated as no 2 are alike.  Samsung puts too many custom interfaces into Android and doesn't implement them across the board or update previous models with the new OS settings.While the tablet is excellent and great for the short term don't plan on it lasting for more than 2 years and it having no resale value at that time since it never gets updates.  I don't really like iPads but they have much longer life spans as they get yearly updates across the board.

Reviews.Title: Check the RAM and SD Card Limitations Before Buying
Reviews.Author: Alfred J. Badger
Reviews.Content: Buyer Beware:  I purchased the Samsung 8.0, expecting to have 16 gigabytes of usable internal memory because Samsung and the dealerships advertised this tablet as having 16 gigabytes of internal memory. However, when I bought and activated this Samsung tablet, I learned that we have access to a little over 9 of those 16 gigabytes advertised.Now, I am not new to the tablet market and believe it is reasonable to expect 16 gigabytes of usable internal memory when the product advertises this memory and shows 16 gigabytes on the box in which the product is packaged. Therefore, I cannot help be feel that some level of false advertising was used here.The other storage-related issue that bugs me about the way Samsung packages its information is that when I purchased a product with supposedly 16 gigabytes of internal memory, it also sells the concept of  allowing me to add my own SD micro card of up to 64 gigabytes. This feature was a major selling point for me. This seemed reasonable to me since 16 gigabytes is not that much device memory anyway. So imagine my surprise when I found that the Android OS and some of its apps limit my use of that 64 gigabytes of memory on my SD card.Although the Samsung 8.0 camera allows me to change the storage  from the internal memory to the SD card, many other apps like the Google Play Books does not. Since one of the reasons I purposed the Samsung 8.0 was to read my purchased books on Google Play Books, I was very surprised and dismayed to learn that over 3 gigabytes of my usable 9 gigabytes on the Samsung Note 8.0 were taken up by five books. This is unacceptable.Ironically, I do like the overall speed, functionality, and form of my Samsung 8.0. However, had I known all these limitations to and misleading information about the storage size and SD limitations, I would not have purchased this product. I am only writing this review so that you have this information before you purchase this product. If the storage restrictions are not an issue for you, it is a decent product. Otherwise, you might see what else is available for you use. Thank you.

Reviews.Title: Updated:  Stay away!!!!  The updates totally killed this device!!!!  Previously  Was:  Mostly great, some not so great...
Reviews.Author: Loonie "Loonie"
Reviews.Content: Is there a 0 star rating?  Originally I rated this 5 stars....read on for the dire consequences....I am updating my review 4 months later after spending 6+ hours on the phone today with Samsung.DO NOT BUY!!!!!!!!!At this point, I would NEVER BUY ANOTHER SAMSUNG PRODUCT AGAIN!!!  Like NEVER EVER!!!  I just spent OVER 6 hours on the phone with customer service/technical support and remote-in people.  I believe that this is about the updates which totally ruin the device.  As you can see by my initial review below, I loved the device initially.  I did not do any updates for over a month, not even the initial ones with this replacement device from Amazon.  At that point, I was loving the machine.  Then, I found that the initial updates made irreversible changes, even with rebooting and factory data reset it did not solve the issues.  They also told me once you do the updates, the only way to get the "known bad updates" off of the device is to send the device to them for a few weeks for them to get it to out of box condition.  They refuse to send new device or give refund.  I started calling in mid January with these issues.  I was told they would be fixed with the next update.  Wrong!  Instead, things have just gotten worse and worse WITH EACH UPDATE.  More things wrong with every update.  Do not update your device!!!  Even one of the tech people says he has automatic updates permanently off.  I should have returned to Amazon in January as it was still under warranty, however, Samsung reps kept telling me the issues would be fixed with the next update.  Nothing got fixed.  Things only became worse.  MUCH WORSE!!!1. The S-Planner calendar in List mode puts your calendar items on the WRONG DAY.  But, it doesn't shift everything to the wrong day, only some things, so you can't just mentally think everything is one day off as you don't know which items are on the correct day and which are on the wrong day.2.  I am bounced off the internet for no reason with the apology "internet connection is lost", however, there was no problem with the internet connection at the location I was at, it was the device.3.  I get com.android. is not working message and it bounces you off everything, internet and all.  Everything you were doing is lost.4.  The Awesome Note HD and S Note programs will just quit with no backup to what you were doing.5.  Polaris files disappear without notice after saving. I can only see them under the Awesome Note application.7.  There are many more issues, but I am tired of typing about them.... I have been on the phone for OVER 6 hours just today and I still have not been able to get my data off the device (with the help from both the tech support and remote help people) and they still cannot tell me how to off-load all my data to my computer.  What is with that?  Yet, they will take it back for 4 weeks to put it back to out of box condition, although all the updates will still be on it.  And all of my data that I cannot retrieve will be OBLITERATED!!!So, without being able to move my data off of the Galaxy Note 8, they are offering to wipe the device, (after I send it in to them).  They do not understand that I may actually need some of that data and that IT WILL NOT BE RETRIEVABLE AFTER THEY WIPE IT.BOO ON 'EXECUTIVE' CUSTOMER SERVICE FOR SAMSUNG.  THEIR POLICIES ARE RIDICULOUS.  THEY CANNOT GIVE ME A NEW DEVICE TO LOAD MY DATA TO, SO I AM TOTALLY OUT OF LUCK.  I HAVE TO KEEP THIS PIECE OF CRAP BECAUSE I CAN'T OFFLOAD MY IMPORTANT DATA.  SAMSUNG does not know how to offload my data.  If I hear them say they can only do and such one more time (which includes throwing away my data, I will croak.I will note that I did speak to a couple of tech people and one of the remote people were very helpful in trying to get to the bottom of the issue, but when they leave you saying that they have to do further research to see if it is even possible, then there is no hope.  They connect you to executive customer service who tells you to send it in.  With your data still on it.  SamSUNG STINKS!  DO NOT BUY SAMSUNG PRODUCTS!IF Samsumg finally gets off the stick and fixes this issue, I will re-post here, but I am guessing that this was a total waste of $400.00 and countless hours of my time as I have been trying to get this fixed for 3 months now.  I could seriously use that money for things other than a broken box.  I'm going back to paper and pencil, at least nothing happens to a paper calendar and paper notes, etc.  Daytimer here I come.  Larger sure, but you won't lose all your data because the box doesn't work right and the company won't do the right thing and replace it despite their people not being able to fix it.Here was my original review:  Lots to love with this little tablet.  The pen, to be able to convert your handwriting to text.  Voice recognition, so you can speak to write a note in text.  Lots and lots of little surprises of what this device can do.  The 360 degree photos are great!Couple of things not quite right, so I am sending back for another:It says it is 16GB.  When you open it up it clearly says it only has 9.85GB TOTAL. Tried reloading, but nothing got this fixed so am getting another.There are times when the handwriting feature does not work, even when  try to put  in the mode.  Can't figure out y.

Reviews.Title: Good tablet, bad price
Reviews.Author: Clifford W Coleman
Reviews.Content: When looking at smaller-than-9-inch tablets, it really comes down to the Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0 and the Google Nexus 7 (2013).Both devices have enough RAM and CPU power to run practically any app or game.The Samsung Note 8.0 has a few pros and consPros:8 InchWacom digitizer and stylus for drawing and handwritingSamsung's split screen multitasking mode that allows you to run 2 apps at the same timeSD card for storage expansionCons:not as high res as the new Nexus 7 and it's an inch bigger so that even lower pixel density.  Not a big deal for me.  I have never had an issue reading anything on this screen and video still looks great.much more expensiveslower to get updates (the wifi version just got 4.2)  Not really an issue since most Android updates now come through the Play Store service.has a dedicated "menu" button instead of an app switch button.  A dedicated menu button means that you never know when a menu button is actually going to do something, where as an onscreen menu button only shows up when it has a function.  All Samsung devices are built this way, and it is a poor design decision.Samsung Touchwiz is kind of ugly, but you can install your own launcher and you will never see it outside of the system menu and notification shade.So for me the biggest drawback was the price difference.  I purchased mine and my wife Note 8.0 tablets as referbs and they work great.  But if you have to buy new, I think the price difference makes the Nexus 7 a better buy.
